answers.answer: A lot of pressure when the push on your stomach.  I had an ok c-section with my one child but they had a hard time putting the neddle in my back which took about 45min.  that sucked - doesn't mean it will happen to you.  Other then that you feel pressure when they take the baby out very odd feeling.  After they took the baby out I was shaking pretty bad but they said all normal.  I got up that night but it hurt like hell.  You are in pain but it last only a couple of weeks at least for me.  I took pain pills for about a week.  I still have no feeling where they cut me open dr said it will take time to get it back. thats my story.
Was yours planned or emergency? Did you get a epidural or spinal? I'm due for one this Friday and am getting very anxious and nervous. I'm so scared of the needle going into my back.

I had a scheduled c-section, but ended up having it done 5 days earlier because my blood pressure kept going up.  I had a spinal, which did not hurt, just a little pinching feeling.  They put the cathader in after my spinal took affect, so I didn't feel that either.  Both my daughters were born by c-section, and both times I didn't like the way I felt during the procedure.  The feeling of being numb was very uncomfortable to me.  The first time, I remember getting really itchy all over, and couldn't stop scratching my face during the c-section.  I talked to the anesthesiologist this time (3-1/2 weeks ago), and he made sure the itchy feeling was kept to a minimum.  I did feel like I was going to throw up this time, but again, I just kept talking to the anesthesiologist, and he gave me something for that too.  So I never did throw up, thank goodness!  Also, the procedure was so quick...they started a little after 1 in the afternoon, and my baby was born at 1:20...then all I could do was watch her, as they cleaned her up, etc.  Then DH brought her over to me and seriously, I completely forgot that I was still on the operating table.  That moment when the baby is born makes the whole thing worth it!

Yes my was planned and it was a spinal.  I don't care what anyone says it hurt really bad.  I think the dr sucked because after 45min they called in another and he got it first try.  I had about 5 little holes in my back.  The one dr really hurt because I was feeling pain in my arms and legs but when the other one came it was fine.  It is not common to take so long because I had calcium deposits in my back that is why it took so long and it was hard.  The only thing I can say is relax because I was so tense because I was scared.  The other thing is you have to bend forward and arch your back and your belly is in the way :-)  If you relax and do what they say it is better.  you will be ok

My c- section was planned and was an absolute breeze!!  The epidural or spinal doesn't hurt really at all. The local to numb you was just a small pinch. I'm relatively skinny, though, so maybe my spine was easily felt.As far as the procedure itself, I felt nothing, not even when they 'warned' me about all the pressure. Plus never felt nauseaus or anything...just so excited to see my baby. That was a suprise b/c she was slimey and whitish...Took less than 30 mins to close me up and off I went to the recovery room to nurse. It was all a wonderful experience!Note they won't let your husband / partner in til after the spinal and draping!

oh, and I did feel a ton of pressure during the procedure, which was uncomfortable, but not painful.  The recovery is painful.  I made sure to walk as soon as possible after this last one, which I think helped so much.  I still am sore, but it is not too bad.  I don't need any medication or anything, and every day gets better.  Make sure to take things slow, it is major surgery!

i had a very good c-section experience, i didn't feel anything but sleepy and tired during the surgery, i was in a very bad mood, that what bother me, i wanted to cry and i couldn't do it because of the anesthesia(spelling?)

the epidural did not hurt me at all, you have just to be held by a nurse so you don't move. the pressure they put on my stomach when tney wanted to get the baby out was the hardest thing. i did not walk untill 2 days after the surgery and that was very painful but it is ok.

my spinal did not bother me at all, and i HATE needles. i didn't mind feeling numb either. i didn't know when they started cutting- it just felt like that were pressing gently on my belly. i think they were halfway done when i realized they actually started, and i only figured it out because i could hear the dr asking for various instruments. there was A LOT of pressure on the top of my abdomen when they delivered her, primarily because the nurse was practically jumping in my chest to push her out. it didn't hurt though- just felt like someone pushing real hard on my chest. after that i started to get very very intense chest pains. it felt like it was shooting all the way through to my back. the anesthesiolgist said it was common,and due to heart burn. it got much worse and very intense,and i started to panic. he quickly put something into my IV which provided instant relief, and i pretty much slept through the rest of the procedure while they closed me up.recovery sucked, i won't lie. i had preeclampsia, so i had to get magnesium sulfate for 24 hrs. i was so drugged up, that for the first day or two, i barely recognized or cared that i had a baby. but i suspect that's because i was so sick, and because i didn't get to go straight to a mother/baby room like most people do because i had to be monitored. all the c-sections i see on TV like the Baby Story, the moms are alert and happy during the procedure, and they cry when they see the baby. it didn't really register with me. but like i said, i was very sick. i could barely stay awake while i was being wheeled in to the room to get my spinal.it may not sound like much, but a lot of my misery beforehand came from the fact that i couldn't eat or drink. the dr called me monday morning at 8 AM and told me i had to go to the hospital (based on results from tests done friday). i hadn't eaten or had anything to drink since the night before. my procedure was at 5 PM. i had terrible heart burn, i felt like **** from not being able to eat, and i was so thirsty i thought i'd die. they wouldn't even give me ice chips. i wasn't allowed to drink after the procedure either. if i am required to have a c-sec again next time, i will make sure they schedule it in the am.definitely make sure you have help after having the baby. the thing i found hardest when i got home was trying to get up from the couch while taking care of the baby. and my baby was tiny (4 wks early). we had moved downstairs because i wasn't allowed to go up and down stairs (once or twice a day max, according to dr).

Mine was an emergency C-Section, so I had an Epidural.  It was scary because of the circumstances, but the actual procedure was alright.   It was a lot of pressure, pushing and pulling, a lot of tugging.  I had some pain during mine, but they just added me more pain medications.

Oh, and I couldn't see the baby being born, my DH wasn't allowed in until just before they took the baby out, and I wasn't able to see the baby immediately afterwards.I ate immediately after the surgery (I hadn't eaten in almost 48 hours), and even at nearly 3 weeks I'm not 100%.  My stomach is still very very tender and driving in a car can still be painful (I'm not allowed to drive for another 3-5 weeks).

question: I know this has probably been asked before, but what can I expect during the actual c-section?  I'm starting to get really anxious about it.  I'm expecting triplets, so it will definitely be a c-section, and I've been watching tons of them on TV, but it seems liek there's always stuff they don't tell you...  I'm really worried about throwing up during - how many of you did?  It seems like it would not be good to be throwing up with your abdominal muscles cut open.  What was the worst part of your c-sections?  I want all the nitty gritty details so I'm prepared!  Thanks!
title: C-section Questions
